bibl.title: Letter from W.C. Hausheer to Wickliffe Rose, November 15, 1922

div1.p: Hausheer reports that their yellow fever findings in Surinam proved negative, but yellow fever is present in Sierra Leone.

div1.head: Letter from W.C. Hausheer to Wickliffe Rose, November 15, 1922
div1.opener:
COPY
ANKYLOSTOMIASIS COMMISSION
Paramaribo, Surinam
P.O. Box 349
November 15,1922
Dear Mr. Rose:
div1.p:
In answer to your letter of October 19, I wish to say that we
have instituted a searching inquiry in regard to the question of yellow fever.

The Medical Inspector General has taken the colony from British
Guiana to Paramaribo and I have taken it from French Guiana to Paramaribo.

I returned from Albina this morning but Dr. Wolff has not as yet
returned. Tomorrow I will complete the Commewyne area and will then be able
to complete my report.

Up to the present time our findings in Surinam have been negative.
On the other hand the authorities of French Guiana tell me they have received
French advice that Yellow Fever has existed in Sierra Leone since before
September 1922. They have promised to forward to me a copy of this informa-
tion. On the other hand from unofficial sources I heard that the “William E.
Burnham” had been smuggling off of Brazil. This latter information could
only be verified by laying out the ship's course from her books.

In any case cooperation by this Government has been all that could
be asked and it has resulted in a sudden cleaning up of Paramaribo that we
otherwise would not have had.
I will send you complete reports of the investigation on the next mail.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, (Signed) W. C. Hausheer Mr. Wickliffe Rose
General Director
International Health Board
61 Broadway, N.Y.
P.S. I neglected to mention that the “William E. Burnham” landed at Mungo
and New Amsterdam, but at no time did she come up the river to Paramaribo.
W.C.H.
